billsco

Country music legend Buck Owens has passed away. This guy was as original as a breath of fresh air in his heyday. His sound was unique--very catchy songs--and was enhanced with the addition of his lead guitar player, Don Rich, who provided tight backup vocals and snappy Fender guitar work. Rich was killed in a motorcycle accident at the height of Owens' career, and I felt Buck never recovered from it.
 
 But he came to be known as the pioneer of the Bakersfield sound, and irritated a lot of people (me included) when he snubbed the Nashville sound in some disparaging comments. (This was another movement spearheaded by Chet Atkins, who produced lush arrangements which reached out to new audiences. I thought both sounds were legitimate, but I quickly forgave Owens.)
 
 He gained a lot of fans with his long-standing hosting duties on Hee Haw also, which became his new focus after his recording career declined.
Alan Ryan

I'd forgotten about Buck. Haven't heard his distinctive honky-tonk sound (played on the radio) for many years........
 
 I like the music of his one time associate Merle Haggard - who I suppose is still alive? 
 
 Bob Wills is mentioned as an early influence on Buck. I also like his stuff - especially when Tommy Duncan worked with him. Though I suppose that his compulsive chattering, even when Leon McAuliffe had the lead, is a turn off for some.
georged

I like the music of his one time associate Merle Haggard - who I suppose is still alive? 
 

 
 Also one of my favorites, a fine voice. He was married to Buck Owens ex-wife Bonnie Owens 1965-78. 
 
 http://www.gactv.com/legends/bios/haggard_m.html
billsco

Merle Haggard is still a going concern, another way of saying he's still breathing. What a phenomenal artist he is. I put him at the top of my homemade most-important-artist-of-the-decade list for the 1970's. I just heard one of his many hits the other day called, "Always Wanting You (But Never Having You") and learned it was written with Dolly Parton on his mind.
 
 It appears you have a well-rounded knowledge and appreciation of the American Songbook. Bob Will was an influence to a whole generation of singers, and has grown large in the psyche of Western Swing. 
 
 This may be a good time to ask your opinion on Jim Reeves and the Nashville Sound he was associated with. I know he had a large fan base in England.
Alan Ryan

I put him at the top of my homemade most-important-artist-of-the-decade list for the 1970's. I just heard one of his many hits the other day called, "Always Wanting You (But Never Having You") and learned it was written with Dolly Parton on his mind.
 
 It appears you have a well-rounded knowledge and appreciation of the American Songbook. Bob Will was an influence to a whole generation of singers, and has grown large in the psyche of Western Swing. 
 
 This may be a good time to ask your opinion on Jim Reeves and the Nashville Sound he was associated with. I know he had a large fan base in England.

 I've been a fan of country music all my life. My tastes range from Traditional Country through Western Swing to Honky-Tonk and Bluegrass. 
 
 I associate the Nashville Sound with Chet Atkins, Patsy Cline, Jim Reeves, and Eddy Arnold (among many others). I don't know whether it's fair to say that it developed as a deliberate attempt to capture pop and rock audiences. But I know some country purists regard it as having a slick commercial production sound that is a 'betrayal' of 'true' country music values. 
 
 I don't go along with that sort of contempt for crossover music. 
 
 Gentleman Jim still has a fan base over here - but I guess not very large now. His fine baritone voice and velvet orchestrations created a beautiful sound that will always make me stop and listen.
billsco

I've been a fan of country music all my life. My tastes range from Traditional Country through Western Swing to Honky-Tonk and Bluegrass. 

 
 All good music. Bluegrass has Alison Krauss to thank for its resurgence.
 
 
 

 I associate the Nashville Sound with Chet Atkins, Patsy Cline, Jim Reeves, and Eddy Arnold (among many others). I don't know whether it's fair to say that it developed as a deliberate attempt to capture pop and rock audiences. But I know some country purists regard it as having a slick commercial production sound that is a 'betrayal' of 'true' country music values. 
 
 I don't go along with that sort of contempt for crossover music. 

 
 Yeah, that was the big scandal. Why do some people think they get to define what is within the boundaries of a certain musical genre? Country music was floundering in the late 50's after Hank died. Everything and everyone tried to be another Hank. The Nashville Sound was the first to break out of the box, spearheaded by the genius of Chet Atkins. When Chet was asked what the Nashville Sound was, he'd jingle the coins in his pocket. He found a new direction for it, and attracted vast new audiences. So did Buck. 
 
 

 Gentleman Jim still has a fan base over here - but I guess not very large now. His fine baritone voice and velvet orchestrations created a beautiful sound that will always make me stop and listen. 

 
 I grew up on Reeves. I find his voice very pleasing to my ears.
Jim Colyer
Buck Owens was making good records in the mid-1960s.
georged

Not to hijack the thread, but who's next from that country music era? The Hag and Willie ran hard all those years, probably harder than Owens. Haggard's raising a brand new family but Willie hasn't slowed down after the IRS eliminated his retirement fund.
Alan Ryan

Who might be next for the Grim Reaper? I believe Kitty Wells, George Jones, and Don Gibson are all still around. Though I'm not sure whether they should be counted within the era of Buck Owens.
 
 If Earl Scruggs is still picking, he's in his eighties.
georged

 Not only still picking, he's still touring.

George Jones is hospitalized now but is expected to make a full recovery. My money's on Eddie Arnold.

Another couple of real oldies still knocking about (I think) are Charlie Louvin and Ralph Stanley. 
 
 
 Yesterday, I downloaded half a dozen of Buck's hits from iTunes.

Speaking of iTunes, I finally transferred many of my favorite singles to my iTune catalog of songs I purchased. Now when I spin the needle (play the songlist for you younguns) it is pure bliss.
Alan Ryan
Going into my iTunes library is like visiting Nostalgia City. Nearly every musician in it is dead !

jim's trucking

All good music. Bluegrass has Alison Krauss to thank for its resurgence.
 
 
 
 
Amen, brother! I have Alison playing at work sometimes all day long. A friend made me a great CD of various songs from her beginning to present day hits. She's not just bluegrassy though.
Waxy

I've been meaning to reply to this thread for long time now, I just haven't known how.
 
 It's hard to put it into words. I'm 30, but I was raised on these artists, my dad always had them playing in the shop, the truck, apparently the steady kick drum beat of Waylon Jennings even used to calm me in the crib. They're a part of me, and always take me to my "happy place", I never tire of them.
 
 I've got a vivid memory of almost being laughed out of my Grade 9 music class when we were asked write down a list who our favourite artists were, and the teacher read them out loud. While everyone else was listing Bon Jovi, Guns n Roses, Madonna, Mariah Carey, etc... I said Waylon Jennings, Merle Haggard, Willie Nelson and George Jones. Even the teacher was laughing as he read them, we never did see eye to eye for the next four years after that LOL.
 
 I hate seeing my heroes pass away. I saw Waylon live when I was about 12, I knew it was special, but didn't fully grasp it at the time. I never got closer to him than that in person, only through his music. I'm not ashamed to admit I cried the day he died.
 
 There's a few left, notably the others on my favourites list, who I go to see every time they come to town, but it won't be long, and all I'll have is the records, because with very precious few exceptions, they're not making any more like that. 
 
 The records, I'll always have the records.
 
 Waxy
georged

Amen, brother! I have Alison playing at work sometimes all day long. A friend made me a great CD of various songs from her beginning to present day hits. She's not just bluegrassy though.

 
 I appreciate her talent and have followed her career from day one, but always wish they'd include a banjo in the group even though I know Jos and her voice pitch are difficult to mix.

 I sure know what you mean, Waxy. My wife probably gets tired of hearing me say, "I sure miss Waylon". A bittersweet feeling sweeps over me when I hear his songs. Since I'm over 50 now, he represented an era for me when I was in my prime, or as Segar says, when my steps were quick and light. Since I've never experienced what it's like to be old, I can only guess the wistfulness I feel so strongly when hearing his music is just a natural part of living. The sweet overpowers the bitter though by a good measure.
billsco

I appreciate her talent and have followed her career from day one, but always wish they'd include a banjo in the group even though I know Jos and her voice pitch are difficult to mix.

 
 I thought Ron Block was primarily a banjo player in Union Station, alternating between rythmn guitar and a Gibson banjo for many of her and their songs.
 
 Jerry Douglas is without doubt the best dobro player. Have you heard "The Boy Who Wouldn't Hoe Corn"? Outstanding dobro work in a minor tuning, backed by Block's banjo picking.
Alan Ryan

Jerry Douglas is without doubt the best dobro player. Have you heard "The Boy Who Wouldn't Hoe Corn"? Outstanding dobro work in a minor tuning, backed by Block's banjo picking.
 
 
 Jerry "Flux" Douglas is a monarch of the dobro.
 
 If you love dobro playing there's a fine Sugar Hill CD called "The Great Dobro Sessions : A Gathering of Resophonic Pickers".
 
 Jerry Douglas, Tut Taylor, Josh Graves, Mike Auldridge, and others, with Vassar Clements on fiddle, and Bela Fleck on banjo, etc. etc. 
 
 A great album and a Grammy Award Winner - if that means anything.
georged

I thought Ron Block was primarily a banjo player in Union Station, alternating between rythmn guitar and a Gibson banjo for many of her and their songs.
 
 Jerry Douglas is without doubt the best dobro player. Have you heard "The Boy Who Wouldn't Hoe Corn"? Outstanding dobro work in a minor tuning, backed by Block's banjo picking.

 
 I haven't heard much banjo other than melody from Union Station when backing up Krause's ballads in quite a few years. Though I appreciate Krause's talent and listen to her music, I prefer the sound of bluegrass instruments to vocals. As an example, on their Lonely Works Both Ways album, Krause's solo ballads with banjo accompaniment are few and far between, but other songs make up for it. 
 
 That's somewhat common with local groups here (I haven't traveled in some time) who have a high pitch lead vocalist (male and female). If they have a good sound person the banjo picker can be toned down, but I often see the banjo & fiddle spotted 10-15' from the vocalist working melody, infrequently let out for a brief time to regenerate the audience mood. Most vocalists here prefer acoustic instruments as primary accompaniment because they aren't as dominant and the music of most acts with a decent vocalist is arranged around the vocals. It takes one hell of a voice to match a hot banjo or fiddle. Loretta Lynn discovered that early on.
billsco

 A great album and a Grammy Award Winner - if that means anything.

 
 iTunes has the album. Wow, 21 songs on it! I may have to purchase that.
